By JERRY NESER
For those Hopkins students
facing daily parking problems on
the Homewood campus, there
will be little or no relief in the
near future, according to Dr.
James Walker, Physics, Chairman
of the Campus Traffic and
Parking Committee.
"The basic problem, one that
1:m convinced we will always
have, is that there are just too
many people for too few places,"
said Walker.
George Weinbach, Director of
Campus Security, pointed out
that there are exactly 1181
parking spaces on campus to
accommodate more than 8500
evening, day school student,
faculty and employee permit
holders. He added that the 1240
day school students with permits
attempt daily to park in less than
580 allotted spaces, including 66
parking meter spaces.
Walker said, "The situation is
so bad, that students and faculty
members arriving on campus
after ten o'clock in the morning

are usually forced to park
illegally."
According to Walker, many
women at Hopkins have recently
preferred not to use the more
distant lots, such as the Wyman
Park Drive area, for safety
reasons. He said that this had
created a new problem, and now
his committee is contending with
the undesirability of certain
spaces along with the lack of
room.
Other problems cited by
Walker include the illegal use of
the lower lots by people from the
Public Health Hospital, medical
students who park at Homewood
and then use the shuttle bus, and
the use of faculty parking places
by relatives.
Walker could see no single
solution to the problem, but
added "Sometimes I ride a
bicy cle to school; if enough
students were to follow this
trend, bicycles could be a
definite answer to the parking
situation."
"Although I agree that the

Hopkins money eaters
parking is not good," Walker
said, "the situation is much
better than at most other
universities. For the student who
arrives early, the parking of his
car is more than tolerable."
— At the present time the
Parking Committee is simply
struggling to keep the available
spaces well apportioned," said
Walker, "But we need the
approval of the entire
community if we are to
succeed."

4 course-4 credit course load proposed
The Committee on
Undergraduate Studies (CUS) is
examining the possibility of
reducing the present
undergraduate course load and
instituting a system of
self-scheduled exams.
Dean for Academic Programs
and CUS Chairman, Sigmund
Susskind, stated that this year
the Committee will evaluate "the
course load, the present credit
system versus alternate systems,
and the proposals of various
sub-committees of the CUS."
Old Business
The proposal to change the
present semester course load to a
four course, four credit system
was made last year by Mindy
Farber, then a member of the
CUS. The Academic Council
returned this proposal to the

Committee for revisions.
At the first CUS meeting this
year, several faculty members of
the group disapproved of the idea
of self-scheduled exams.
According to Susan Moran,
undergraduate representative to
the CUS, the professors were
predominantly against the idea
because "It would be impossible
to grade the exams until all were
turned in."
Popular Fallacy
Also discussed at the meeting
were possible alternatives to the
present course credit system.
Moran mentioned that a possible
drawback to the present system
is that natural science courses
often require more work than
humanities courses even though
they are assigned equal credit
values.

meetings, a number of old and
new proposals were reviewed. A
p;oposed speech course for the
Evening College was rejected
because the Committee felt such
a course would be of value only
to a limited constituency.

Reviewing the intersession
procedure, CUS members
rejected a proposal to make
intersession proposals pass-fail.
In addition, the CUS sent a
letter to the Academic Council
suggesting that professors remain
in the Baltimore area for one or
two weeks following final exams
to consult with students • on
various matters.
Last year, the Committee
allowed undergraduates to
participate in graduate level
courses in their major areas of
study on a pass-fail basis.
Susskind stressed that the
Committeee on Undergraduate
Studies is only an advisory body,
but commented, "serious
recommendations made by the
CUS to the Academic Council
will have considerable impact."

UAC constitution looks for OK
By ROBERT PAULUS
The proposed constitution of
the revived Urban Affairs Council
will come up for ratification at
Wednesday's Student Council
meeting.
Funding for the Council has
not yet been decided upon and
will eventually come through the
Student Activities Commission.
According to Student Council
member and UAC Chairman
Harry Lamb, the academic
objectives; of the Council are
three-tad: to make students
aware of course offerings in
urban affairs, to investigate the
possibility of an urban affairs
major, and to encourage student
interest, and participation in the

Mayor's Fellowship Program.
In addition, Lamb stated that
he hoped that the new Urban
Affairs Council could attract city
officials, and administrators to
talk at Council seminars.
At the present time, 19
undergraduates, mostly freshmen
and sophomores are UAC
members. Lamb said that an
urban affairs major would be
especially helpful for these
people who are going on to
graduate school because it would
"give them time to organize."
Because of the difficulties
involved in arranging academic
credit for an expanded Mayor's
Fellowship program, Lamb said
that the UAC will also be looking

into the "possibility of students
working (in a Mayor's Fellowship
program) for noncredit."
Although he stated that the
UAC may require funding for
publicity and printing costs,
Lamb remarked; "We're not
asking for funding yet, wt even
have old urban affairs
statonary."
The original Urban Affairs
Council was founded in the
spring of 1968 at the same time
as was the Urban Affairs Center.
Dave Boehlke, ex-vice president
of the UAC, stated that
the original Council functioned
successfully through the 1968-69
academic year, before students
began to lose interest in the idea.

established. But, most important of all, is the fact that

By B.H. COHEN
A triumphant performance of Mozart's
Concerto for piano and orchestra in Bb
major redeemed an uneven opening
concert of this season's Sunday evening
Shriver Hall Series.
Featuring pianist Paul Badura-Skoda,
and a radically improved chamber
orchestra from the Baltimore Symphony
under the direction of Sergiu Comissiona,
the all-Mozart program received a very
warm reception from the near-capacity
audience.
Comissiona, over a very brief time, has
transformed the Baltimore. Symphony
into an orchestra which Baltimore, at
least, should be willing to support. His
chamber orchestra, of about thirty-five
players, represents the best of the
Symphony, with the potential to perform
difficult works with precision and
intensity, qualities which were apparent
in spurts during Sunday's performance.
More ambitious than prudent
The program was more ambitious than
prudent, opening with a mature
symphony, and featuring a concerto
before the intermission, the performance
concluding with a serenade for strings and
timpani, before the concluding concerto.
The symphony, no. 33 in Bb major,
was a showpiece for Comissiona's finely
honed violin section, to which Mozart
turned for long pastoral allegro assai, and,
after developments through the entire
orchestra. for tense counterpoint, and for

longer near-serenades. Only in the
andante was there rich development of
Mozart's subsequent symphonies. Here,
though still dominated by the violins, the
orchestra reached great heights, moving
through the registers with precisions,
following Mozart closely. The andante
ends on a firm note, as the orchestra spins
the symphony's themes into a coherent
statement.
The ensuing minuetto, though not
written for great effect, sounded very
thin, as the orchestra failed to capture
any excitement which might have been in
the score. The movement ended with the
repetition of the symphony's opening
theme.
Comissiona drew out of his players a
rich and precise second allegro assai. The
movement again opened inthe violins,
spreading through the other strings, and
was finally taken up by the full orchestra.
The violins again became dominant,
challenging first the rest of the orchestra
with -short punctuations, then playing a
series of developments before a rich
unfolding of the entire orchestra.
Also before the intermission,
Badura-Skoda performed the Concerto in
A major. The orchestra developed
rapidly, introducing an extended solo.
Throughout this concerto, Badura-Skoda
seemed to play right hand diversion
without a firm control, and with little
definition. Though the concerto's
numerous pauses were utilized to effect,

the overall impression was of a work
presented without adequate rehearsal.
Following the intermission, the
orchestra, now made up of strings and a
single percussionist, presented an inspired
Serenade no. 6 in D major, playing a
potentially incoherent piece with
restraint and precision, and, for the only
time during the entire concert, with
consideration for Mozart's dynamics.
Controlled performance
Returning for the finale, Badura-Skoda
presented a controlled performance in the
Bb concerto, one of Mozart's last
concerti. The first movement, an allegro,
begins with the orchestra developing a
sweeping passage, interrupted by the
horns. Another theme is introduced in
the violins, spread through the orchestra,
introducing a piano solo of sustained
power. After the orhcestra's resurgence,
the movement ends as the violins fade
out.
The graceful legato began with a
restrained piano solo, with the horns
eventually introducing the full orchestra,
which again subsides. Once again, the
pianist showed himself firmly in
command of the music, articulating each
phrase masterfully.
The concluding allegro, much lighter
than the previous two movements, was
long and repititious, though played
superbly. Fortunately, the coda was brief,
emphatically ending the piece and the
concert on a note of excitement.

theological aspects of death and
dying was the subject of this
week's Sunday Experience in
Levering Hall.
The morning's speakers, Rev.
Clyde R. Shallenberger, Dr.
Ronald W. Marris, and Dr.
Thomas P. Duffy, commented
breifly on society's failure to deal
adequately with the fact of
death.
The Rev. Shallenberger, head
of the chaplaincy services at
Johns Hopkins Hospital, charged
that our society "treats death as
unreal." "People don't die", he
continued, "they pass away, go
into cardiac arrest, or enter their
heavenly home. The word is
simply not used in conversation."
Shallenberger also took note
of the fact that "we refuse to
relate to people in the process of
dying - we avoid the topic." He
noted that through society's

refusal to discuss the fact of
death, "the person is denied the
opportunity to be comfortable in
relating his own deepest
feelings." This results in pain,
loneliness, and a feeling of loss of,
self.
Dr. Duffy, a hematologist at
Hopkins Hospital, explained that
in his field he cared for patients
whom
the great majority of
"have illnessess that cause death
in weeks or months." Duffy
stated his job is to keep the
family educated in terms of the
progression of the disease, but
not to make them overanxious
"so their own fears won't be
overwhelmed."
Duffy feels that though the
modern, sophisticated
"mechanical care" can keep
people "alive", its use tends to
forget that "the patient is a
human being." Dr. Marris, who
offers a course in death and
dying in the Evening College,
stated that "to be fully alive

necessitates confronting and
working through the realization
that we are finite...to be truly
free we must look death full in
the face." After doing so, "we
must reorder our priorities and
reevaluate our lifestyles." Marris
explained.
"There must be a greater
collective sensitivity in response
to death at all levels of life, said
Marris. We must be able to take
in the fact of death, and then
reevaluate that which is
important."

Footballers upset by Towson
By BARRY KEMELHOR
Johns Hopkins Blue Jays had
dreams of soaring to great heights
after their most satisfying
Georgetown victory a week ago,
but they were unceremoniously
brought back to earth last
Saturday by the Towson State
Tigers, 20-8.
The Jays were totally
outplayed by an inferior Tiger
team that had lost 13 straight
games and had failed to score in
its last four encounters. In
addition, Towson was without its
regular quarterback and star
linebacker, both of whom were
injured. But what the Tigers
lacked in ability, they more than
made up for inspiration and
opportunism.
Fanatics
Before a wet but fanatic
Homecoming crowd at Burdick
Field, the fired up Tigers picked
off three Jack Thomas aerials and
pounced on two Blue Jay
fumbles to key the victory. The
sloppy field conditions stymied
the offenses of both teams, but
Towson managed to come up
with the bigger plays, and fully
deserved to win.
The chief heroes for the Tigers
were senior halfback Miek Wells,
who rushed for 126 yards rn 30
carries and scored two
touchdowns, and
newly converted linebacker Rick
DeMilt, who was credited with a
phenomenal 19 tackles.
Bright Spots
The only bright spots in an
otherwise dismal afternoon for
the Blue Jays were defensive end
Craig Stevens, who receovered a
fumble and intercepted a pass;
rapidly improving cornerback
Rick Kramer, who also fell on a
fumble and generally sparkled on
defense; and halfback Timmy
Doyle, who had missed the last
two games due to injuries, but

recovered enough to gain 71
yards and account for almost the
entire Hopkins attack.
The game resembled a
mud-slinging contest for most of
the first quarter with neither
team mounting much of an
offense. But with three minutes
to go, Mike Wells suddenly
brought the crowd to its feet by
sloshing through the quagmire on
a 67-yard return of a Jack
Thomas punt to give the hosts a
7-0 lead.
Bounce
The Jays immediately bounced
back, launching a 54-yard drive
in ten plays - most of them runs
by Doyle - to score the tying
touchdown. Thomas sneaked
over from 2 yards out, and after
the Tigers were penalized half the
distance to the goal line on the
point after touchdown, Doyle
ran for the two point conversion
-to put Hopkins in front at the
half, 8-7.
Let Down
The advantage was short-lived,
however, because Billy Nolan
fumbled on the fourth play of
the second half, and, Nace
recovered for Towson at the
Hopkins 38. The Jays let down
for just one play following the
miscue, but it was enough to
allow Wells to romp the 38 yards
to paydirt. Nace added the extra
point and the Tigers had a 14-8
bulge.
The game then developed into
a defensive struggle - most
attributable perhaps to the
sloppy, error-prone offenses.
Neither team could generate an
attack, nor could they capitalize
on the numerous breaks afforded
by their opponents.
The Blue Jays had one good
chance to score in the second
half, when Kramer recovered a
fumble at the Towson 38, but
Thomas fumbled the ball back to
the Tigers two plays later, and
the comedy of errors continued.

1:m convinced we will always

evening, day school student,
faculty and employee permit

day school students with permits

580 allotted spaces, including 66

members arriving on campus

illegally."

room.

the use of faculty parking places
by relatives.

solution to the problem, but

trend, bicycles could be a
definite answer to the parking
situation."

theological aspects of death and
dying was the subject of this
week's Sunday Experience in
Levering Hall.

Clyde R. Shallenberger, Dr.
Ronald W. Marris, and Dr.
Thomas P. Duffy, commented
breifly on society's failure to deal
adequately with the fact of
death.
The Rev. Shallenberger, head
of the chaplaincy services at
Johns Hopkins Hospital, charged
that our society "treats death as
unreal." "People don't die", he
continued, "they pass away, go
into cardiac arrest, or enter their
heavenly home. The word is
simply not used in conversation."
Shallenberger also took note
of the fact that "we refuse to
relate to people in the process of
dying - we avoid the topic." He
noted that through society's

refusal to discuss the fact of
death, "the person is denied the
opportunity to be comfortable in
relating his own deepest
feelings." This results in pain,
loneliness, and a feeling of loss of,
self.
Dr. Duffy, a hematologist at
Hopkins Hospital, explained that
in his field he cared for patients
whom
the great majority of
"have illnessess that cause death
in weeks or months." Duffy
stated his job is to keep the
family educated in terms of the
progression of the disease, but
not to make them overanxious
"so their own fears won't be
overwhelmed."
Duffy feels that though the
modern, sophisticated
"mechanical care" can keep
people "alive", its use tends to
forget that "the patient is a
human being." Dr. Marris, who
offers a course in death and
dying in the Evening College,
stated that "to be fully alive

necessitates confronting and
working through the realization
that we are finite...to be truly
free we must look death full in
the face." After doing so, "we
must reorder our priorities and
reevaluate our lifestyles." Marris
explained.
"There must be a greater
collective sensitivity in response
to death at all levels of life, said

in the fact of death, and then
reevaluate that which is
important."

Footballers upset by Towson
By BARRY KEMELHOR
Johns Hopkins Blue Jays had
dreams of soaring to great heights
after their most satisfying
Georgetown victory a week ago,
but they were unceremoniously
brought back to earth last
Saturday by the Towson State
Tigers, 20-8.
The Jays were totally
outplayed by an inferior Tiger
team that had lost 13 straight
games and had failed to score in
its last four encounters. In
addition, Towson was without its
regular quarterback and star
linebacker, both of whom were
injured. But what the Tigers
lacked in ability, they more than
made up for inspiration and
opportunism.
Fanatics
Before a wet but fanatic
Homecoming crowd at Burdick
Field, the fired up Tigers picked
off three Jack Thomas aerials and
pounced on two Blue Jay
fumbles to key the victory. The
sloppy field conditions stymied
the offenses of both teams, but
Towson managed to come up
with the bigger plays, and fully
deserved to win.
The chief heroes for the Tigers
were senior halfback Miek Wells,
who rushed for 126 yards rn 30
carries and scored two
touchdowns, and
newly converted linebacker Rick
DeMilt, who was credited with a
phenomenal 19 tackles.
Bright Spots
The only bright spots in an
otherwise dismal afternoon for
the Blue Jays were defensive end
Craig Stevens, who receovered a
fumble and intercepted a pass;
rapidly improving cornerback
Rick Kramer, who also fell on a
fumble and generally sparkled on
defense; and halfback Timmy
Doyle, who had missed the last
two games due to injuries, but

recovered enough to gain 71
yards and account for almost the
entire Hopkins attack.
The game resembled a
mud-slinging contest for most of
the first quarter with neither
team mounting much of an
offense. But with three minutes
to go, Mike Wells suddenly
brought the crowd to its feet by
sloshing through the quagmire on
a 67-yard return of a Jack
Thomas punt to give the hosts a
7-0 lead.
Bounce
The Jays immediately bounced
back, launching a 54-yard drive
in ten plays - most of them runs
by Doyle - to score the tying
touchdown. Thomas sneaked
over from 2 yards out, and after
the Tigers were penalized half the
distance to the goal line on the
point after touchdown, Doyle
ran for the two point conversion
-to put Hopkins in front at the
half, 8-7.
Let Down
The advantage was short-lived,
however, because Billy Nolan
fumbled on the fourth play of
the second half, and, Nace
recovered for Towson at the
Hopkins 38. The Jays let down
for just one play following the
miscue, but it was enough to
allow Wells to romp the 38 yards
to paydirt. Nace added the extra
point and the Tigers had a 14-8
bulge.
The game then developed into
a defensive struggle - most
attributable perhaps to the
sloppy, error-prone offenses.
Neither team could generate an
attack, nor could they capitalize
on the numerous breaks afforded
by their opponents.
The Blue Jays had one good
chance to score in the second
half, when Kramer recovered a
fumble at the Towson 38, but
Thomas fumbled the ball back to
the Tigers two plays later, and
the comedy of errors continued.
